comments:
hi,
I was using Eclipse (Version: 3.0.0, Build id: 200403100800) till yesterday.
When I downloaded (Version: 3.0.0, Build id: 200403170800). I am running a
Windows XP machine with the JDK 1.5.0 beta. My project though uses the JDK
1.4.2_03 version to compile and the launch configs also uses the same 1.4.x JDK.

In the project classpath, I have the following jars in the classpath:
jce1_2_2.jar, sunjce_provider.jar (in that order) followed by the
org.eclipse.jdt.launching.JRE_CONTAINER line. With the older (200403100800)
eclipse version, i am able to run fine, but with the later one, the launch is
not able to get to the javax.crypto.Cipher class (from the jce1_2_2 jar) and so
our authentication mechanism fails.

Could this be resolved easily?

some more info: the jdk/jre installs that i use are just plain vanilla versions
- ie none of the jars/java.policy/java.security files have been updated.

But what is jce1_2_2.jar? It is not part of my JDK vanilla install? The 
sunjce_provider.jar will appear on the bootpath by default (as will all jars 
in the ext directory). Why are you adding them explicitly?
Continue to investigate, but does not look like an M8 stop ship.

What happens if you place the jars in the 'ext' directory of the JRE and the 
launch with nothing extra on your bootpath, but the "JRE System Libaray"?

I tried that - but then i get some error message saying "could not verify
certification" (or something like that - sorry i dont have the exact message
right now).
But, my question would be: why would this stop working if i just upgraded the
eclipse version? I was using the same JDK/JRE with the earlier version - and it
worked fine).
I also tried using the jars that are present in the JDK/JRE by not putting them
in the project classpath (.classpath file) - and the whole thing works with both
versions of eclipse, presumably because the jre container entry in the
.classpath file has all the jars from the lib\ext directory included in it.

i just tried 3.0 M8 (with the vanilla version of the JDK/JRE), and got this: Caused by: java.security.NoSuchAlgorithmException: Cannot find any provider supporting DESede at javax.crypto.Cipher.getInstance(DashoA6275) i will try the suggestion from comment #6

ok - once i replaced all the jars in the JRE with the ones from my project lib,
i get the following error:
Caused by: java.lang.SecurityException: Cannot set up certs for trusted CAs:
java.security.PrivilegedActionException: java.net.MalformedURLException: 
no protocol: US_export_policy.jar
	at javax.crypto.SunJCE_b.<clinit>(DashoA6275)

sorry for bothering - but is there any progress on this bug? i am unable to move
to any later builds due to this defect. If you require any config files (like
the .classpath and/or the .launch file), i would be happy to attach them to this bug
is this in any way related to bug 56665?

I don't know how to reproduce your problem. I'm able to run the example from
http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/guide/security/jce/JCERefGuide.html#Examples
without problem.
Can you provide a small test that shows the problem ?

I don't understand why you add jce1_2_2.jar and sunjce_provider.jar to the build
path/classpath. This 2 libraries are already part of the JRE (in 1.4.x).

found the issue - my bad :-)

the issue was that the 4 jars that i mentioned, were such that 3 of them
occurred before the JRe lib container, and the US_export_policy jar occurred
AFTER the JRE library container. Also, since the jars that I had from my project
were signed using a different algorithm, the US export policy jar could not be
"accessed".

So, now finally I can upgrade to M8!!! 
But the question would still be: why did this work with the integration build
that i mentioned in my original bug comment?
this works for me after i rearranged the project classpath.

traces.message: Cannot find any provider supporting DESede
